results.headline: From the Lips of Desperate Poles in ’44
results.summary_short: “Warsaw Uprising” harnesses archival film from that World War II resistance battle, even using actors to recite what on-camera subjects might have been saying.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Powstanie Warszawskie

results.headline: A Politician Slips, and an Ideal Impostor Steps In
results.summary_short: In “Viva la Libertà,” a twin impersonates his brother, a politician who has dropped out of sight.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Viva la libertà

results.headline: Only One Sugar Plum Fairy a Year
results.summary_short: Serene Meshel-Dillman’s documentary “Getting to ‘The Nutcracker’ ” focuses on the Marat Daukayev School of Ballet in Los Angeles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Getting to the Nutcracker

results.headline: Behind Closed Doors in Both Berlins
results.summary_short: Christian Schwochow’s dramas “The Tower” and “West” deal with paranoia in East and West Berlin for very different people in different decades.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Der Turm

results.headline: Crushed by a Giant, With No White Knight in Sight
results.summary_short: The documentary “The Invisible Front” centers on Lithuania’s quixotic postwar struggle to escape Soviet dominion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invisible Front

results.headline: Lincoln, the Beardless, Ethereal Youth
results.summary_short: In “The Better Angels,” written and directed by A. J. Edwards, Abraham Lincoln spends his boyhood in a rural Indiana paradise.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Better Angels

results.headline: The Psycho, the Starlet and the Voyeur
results.summary_short: In “Open Windows,” a mistreated entertainment blogger accepts an offer to spy on his favorite actress through her computer and phone cameras.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Open Windows

results.display_title: On Any Sunday, The Next Chapter
results.headline: Keeping Wheelies, Kickstands and Helmets in the Family
results.summary_short: Dana Brown — son of the director Bruce Brown, who made the 1971 motorbiking documentary “On Any Sunday” — makes a follow-up to his father’s classic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On Any Sunday, The Next Chapter

results.headline: Scratch Baths From the Recovery Regimen
results.summary_short: In the horror movie “Jessabelle,” a woman returns to her childhood home to recover from a car accident and finds unsettling videotapes of her mother telling fortunes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jessabelle

results.headline: Marriage Is Hard, Physics Is Easy
results.summary_short: Eddie Redmayne stars in James Marsh’s “The Theory of Everything,” a biographical drama about Stephen Hawking’s health, marriage and other struggles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Theory of Everything

results.headline: Let’s Play ‘Scare the Actors’
results.summary_short: Rendlesham Forest in England, site of a famed U.F.O. sighting, plays a leading role in Daniel Simpson’s science-fiction “Hangar 10.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hangar 10

results.headline: Inexperienced, in More Ways Than One
results.summary_short: In “Sex Ed,” Haley Joel Osment plays a teacher who bounces from one humiliation to another.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex Ed

results.headline: Humiliations on the Road From Boy to Man
results.summary_short: “Fugly!,” John Leguizamo’s bittersweet new comedy, mixes narrative and stand-up comedy, embellished with clever animation by Bill Plympton.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fugly!

results.headline: Love, Not Young, but New and Invigorating
results.summary_short: Circumstances bring together two seemingly mismatched characters in the romantic comedy “Elsa & Fred.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elsa & Fred

results.headline: Happiness Is a Warm Robot
results.summary_short: In the animated “Big Hero 6,” a tech-nerd protagonist rises to a challenge with the help of his friends and a doughy robot when evil threatens their metropolis.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Hero 6

results.headline: 30 Years Later, Reliving an Industrial Disaster
results.summary_short: “Bhopal: A Prayer for Rain” dramatizes the buildup to the 1984 poisonous gas leak from a pesticide factory in India, taking historical liberties for effect.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bhopal: A Prayer for Rain

results.headline: Reality, or Artful Dodge?
results.summary_short: Brandy Burre stars as herself in “Actress,” a movie about her own life raising children in the Hudson Valley and yearning to reclaim her acting career.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Actress

results.headline: Hitting the Road to Keep a Holiday Illusion Alive
results.summary_short: “A Merry Friggin’ Christmas” stars Robin Williams in one of his last roles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Merry Friggin' Christmas

results.headline: Off to the Stars, With Grief, Dread and Regret
results.summary_short: In Christopher Nolan’s science-fiction parable “Interstellar,” Earth is dying, and a team of astronauts searches the universe for a new home for the human race.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Interstellar

results.headline: Framing the Viewers, and the Viewed
results.summary_short: “National Gallery,” a documentary, uses that London museum to expose the heart of the network of relationships connecting art, artists, institutions and the public.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of National Gallery
